title: For Sale:  Very Rare - Auto Ordnance, Thompson 1927A3 - 22 lr
postcontent:
The 1927a3 Thompson is a rarely seen and very collectable 22lr semi-auto version of the famous Thompson Sub-Machine gun.  The 1927a3 was made in very limited numbers from 1978- 1992 and this one is one of only 162 made in 1983. 
This A3 is in very good condition and includes 1 - 30 round magazine and a very rare 10 round stick magazine made from an original Thompson 45acp magazine. Stick mags were made to make the 1927a3 legal after the assult rifle ban was passed. 

Illinois residents must have a vaild FOID card and/or FFL license.

title: For Sale:  Springfield 1911 9mm semi-custom target pistol  SPF
postcontent:
SOLD PENDING FUNDS


ADDED STOCK PHOTO W/ SIMILAR GRIPS.  I have original crossed cannon grips as well as better quality VX G-10 grips with blackened screws.

This is the nicest pistol I've ever owned. Trigger breaks like glass and it is a tackdriver. Hate to put it up for sale, but it is too big for me to CCW comfortably and it isn't getting shot at the range. Since I bought this nearly 2 years ago I fired it at the range once, cleaned it, and put it in the safe. Every now and then I took it out to fondle but that's about it. Was carrying a Star BM instead but decided that was too heavy for me as well. I've decided to move away from this caliber altogether.

I have a lightly used Springfield Armory Stainless Loaded 9mm with adjustable sights & ambi safety in the original blue plastic case with papers and all the stuff that came with it, including a Kydex holster and dual mag carrier. Info on this piece is at their website here: http://www.springfield-armory.com/armory.php?version=22

Pistol's prior owner had a great gunsmith lighten the trigger to 2.5#. It is the best trigger job I've ever seen, although it is may be too light for the average shooter.  Breaks like a glass rod.  Perfect trigger.  He stated he only put a few hundred rounds through it before deciding he wanted a .45 instead. I put less than 50 rds through it myself. There are a few minor scuffs on the stainless finish that were there when I bought it -- looks like from the original owner drawing it from the Kydex. I have the original grips but replaced them with VZ Double Diamond in black G-10 which looks nicer and feels great. http://vzgrips.com/gun-grips/1911-pistol-grips-1/double-diamonds-1/double-diamond-black-g10 Aside from that, the only change I made to this piece was to touch up the sights with a bit of nail polish (white on the back, red on the front) which I think is an improvement, but if you don't like it or want to redo it, it is very easily removed with a bit of acetone on a swab.

In addition to the aforementioned Kydex holster (RH), I have several other holsters that I could include, first two I'll throw in for free, willing to work out a deal on the other two. One is a cheapo ambi belt slide that I got for free and never used, the others are really nice. First one is a Galco IWB tuckable w/J-hook (LH). Next is an impossible to find Israeli Front Line IWB with teflon lining (LH). Last is a Galco Miami Classic shoulder rig in like new condition. This is set up for LH, but you can make it RH simply by switching it around, but if you want to get a proper RH holster for a clean draw Optics Planet has one you can add on for about $40 (this is a modular system).  The Front Line And Miami Classic cost me over $200 total and both are LH, and if you want either I will give you a good deal but I will not give them away for free.

I have a total of 7 top quality magazines for this pistol. This takes 9rd mags but one is a Wilson 10rd.

I have well over a grand in this package.

I have reduced my cash price for the gun, 7 mags, 3 holsters, and assorted extras to $775.  It is worth considerably more.  Extra mags go for about $30 each.

Would do an even exchange for an EMP (I can always hope).

For partial trades, I like .25 automatics, and especially like the Beretta Jetfire. Might consider .380 but I'm picky. I like the SIG P230 and the chrome slide LCP.  I would consider a long barreled .38 or a short barreled lightweight 1911 with ambi safety.  No more long guns -- I haven't got any room for them.

I am in no hurry to sell. I will likely regret selling this. But it is impractical for me because my eyes aren't good enough to target shoot and it is too big for me to carry. Someone wants this. Open to reasonable offers but please do not insult me with ridiculous lowballs.

WILL NOT SHIP

NO, YOU CANNOT DISASSEMBLE PISTOL TO "LOOK AT" IT.

NO BAD GUYS

Thanks.

title: For Sale:  HAKIM battle rifle with many extras
postcontent:
Well, since I can't afford an AR-10 or an M-14 I decided to invest in a pair of Egyptian 8mm Hakim battle rifles. They are really cool! Detachable magazine, high powered military round, well designed muzzle brake to eliminate recoil, and a blow forward brass deflector that doubles as the charging handle. The only thing I don't like about this rifle is it is big and heavy.

Well, I swapped my spare for a Mauser + cash a couple months back and am considering letting my primary go as well. Still haven't had a chance to fire it. Bore is nice. This was very well taken care of.

In addition to the standard 10 rd mag, I also have a couple of hi-caps: a 20 rd Federal and a 25 rd ribbed MG-13 mag that was adapted to fit by a Hakim expert (cost nearly a hundred bucks on gunbroker, but it is a good one). Comes with a sling, gas tool, manual, tech sheet, and I can add some ammo as well. Does NOT come with bayonet in pic.

Pics of this fine rifle can be seen in the original sale thread below. Extra hi-cap mag (better quality than the Federal) not in pic.

http://www.armslist.com/posts/84364/denver-colorado-rifles-for-sale-spf-hakim-8mm-bayonet-high-cap-mag-ammo--more

I have mixed feelings about parting with this rifle. I love this thing, even if it is a bit heavy and awkward. This is far more badassed than an AR or an AK. Surplus ammo is cheap and you can get various fire hazard colored tip ammo for it at Tanner. Only thing you don't want to shoot through it is Turkish as it is loaded too hot. Yugo, FN, German all run fine. Gas can be adjusted depending on ammo used.

I'm listing this at $600 CASH right now.

Trades? I want an alloy framed SIG P230. I like long barreled .38 special revolvers and nickle plated .25 automatics. I'd really like an INOX Jetfire. Would consider a chrome slide LCP. Can always use quality .380 and .25 ACP ammo.

Thanks.

title: For Sale:  KP 44 Finish submachine gun semi auto 9mm 4-71 rd drums
location: Naples, Marco, South West Florida, Florida
postcontent:
Website info:

The 'Suomi KP/-31' (Suomi-konepistooli or "Submachine-gun Finland") was a submachine gun (SMG) of Finnish design that was in service during World War II. It was a descendant of the M-22 prototype and the KP/-26 production model, which was revealed to the public in 1925. The Suomi-konepistooli KP/-31 is often abbreviated to Suomi KP.

The Suomi KP/-31 is regarded by many as one of the most successful submachine guns of World War II and it was so successful that many of its features (including the soon developed 71-round drum magazine) were later copied and adopted by the Soviets for their PPD-40 and PPSh-41 submachine guns.[3] The accuracy compared to the mass-produced PPSh-41 was superior however, thanks in part to a noticeably longer barrel, with the same rate of fire and the equally large magazine capacity. The major disadvantage of the Suomi-KP was its high production costs.

The Suomi KP/-31 also incorporated a few new design features, including an arrangement whereby the spring was mounted inside the bolt in order to make the gun shorter. Its 50-round quad-column "Casket" box magazine was more reliable than the early 50-round "bullets loaded nose down" drum magazine, and similar applications were used on the Argentine C-4 submachine gun and present-day 60-round 5.45x39mm AK-74 compatible magazines.

The M-22 and KP/-26 were made by Konepistooli Oy, founded by Master Armorer Aimo Lahti, Captain V. Korpela, Lieutenant Y. Koskinen and Lieutenant L. Boyer-Spoof. The Suomi KP/-31 was designed by Koskinen and Lahti.

The Suomi KP/-31 went into serial production in 1931 by Tikkakoski Oy and most of these weapons were bought by the Finnish Defence Forces. The Finnish Defence Forces were equipped with about 4000 Suomi KP/-31 submachine guns when the Winter War started. During the course of the war, the design was altered with the addition of a muzzle brake, which increased the submachine gun's overall length by 55 mm. The revised version was designated KP/-31 SJR (suujarru, or "muzzle brake"). Aimo Lahti was displeased with this revision, believing that it reduced the weapon's reliability. Ultimately, roughly half of the KP/-31s in Finnish service were of the SJR version. Initially the KP/-31 was issued as a substitute for a light machine gun, and proved inadequate in this role. Instead, soldiers learned by trial and error how to use submachine guns to the best effect. By the time of the Continuation War, Finnish doctrine had been altered to include both a KP/-31 and a light machine gun (usually a captured Degtyaryov DP) in every infantry squad, and by 1943 this had been expanded to two KP/-31s per squad. KP/-31 production continued with the intention of adding a third submachine gun to each squad, but this plan was shelved in 1944 when the Continuation War ended.

A specialized bunker version was also produced in very small numbers (a total of 500 built) in 1941, with a thinner barrel shroud to allow firing through the narrow ports of defensive bunkers. This version lacked a shoulder stock and was equipped with a pistol grip. An even rarer version was produced for use as a secondary gun in the firing ports of Vickers Alt B Type E 6-Ton tanks, but only a few dozen were built before production was canceled due to the outbreak of the Winter War. Production never resumed, as captured Degtyaryov DP machine guns proved far superior in this role. Like the bunker version, the tank version had a pistol grip and no buttstock, and it could be quickly removed from the tank and fitted with a standard barrel shroud for infantry use if needed. The tank version remained in the Finnish Army's inventory through the 1980s, despite the tank it was designed for being retired in 1959, possibly because the Army forgot that they existed.

The Suomi KP was also manufactured under license in Sweden, Denmark, and Switzerland, where it was known as the Hispano-Suiza MP43/44. Tank and pillbox variants were also developed and produced in Finland.

In 2009, a semi-automatic version of the Suomi KP was produced for civilian sale in the United States[citation needed], replacing the receiver and lengthening barrel to meet the standards of the National Firearms Act. I HAVE ONE OF THESE... VERY RARE.. INCLUDES 4 EA 71 ROUND DRUM MAGAZINES... AND STRAP.. 9 MM AMMO AVAILABLE AT A PRICE. THX.

Like the bunker version, the tank version had a pistol grip and no buttstock, and it could be quickly removed from the tank and fitted with a standard barrel shroud for infantry use if needed. The tank version remained in the Finnish Army's inventory through the 1980s, despite the tank it was designed for being retired in 1959, possibly because the Army forgot that they existed.

The Suomi KP was also manufactured under license in Sweden, Denmark, and Switzerland, where it was known as the Hispano-Suiza MP43/44. Tank and pillbox variants were also developed and produced in Finland.

In 2009, a semi-automatic version of the Suomi KP was produced for civilian sale in the United States[citation needed], replacing the receiver and lengthening barrel to meet the standards of the National Firearms Act. title: For Sale:  HAKIM battle rifle w/ hi-caps and lots of good ammo
postcontent:
This is a Hakim battle rifle chambered for 8mm Mauser.  Very few were imported and many of the ones available are not in good shape.  This is one of the nicer ones I've seen.  Bore is clean, overall condition is Excellent.  This rifle was very well taken care of by the prior owner.  Functions flawlessly according to prior owner, and it feeds and extracts snap caps well.

Detachable magazine, high powered military round, well designed muzzle brake to eliminate recoil, and a blow forward brass deflector that doubles as the charging handle.  Very unique design.

In addition to the standard 10 rd mag, I also have a couple of hi-caps: a 20 rd Federal and a 25 rd ribbed MG-13 mag that was adapted to fit by a Hakim expert (cost nearly a hundred bucks on gunbroker, but it is a good one). Comes with a sling, gas tool, tech sheet, a good book about this rifle, and I can add a few hundred rounds of good quality ammo as well (most of it is non-corrosive, no bulk garbage here). Does NOT come with bayonet in pic.

Pic from original sale thread below. Extra hi-cap mag (of much better quality) not in pic.

I have mixed feelings about parting with this rifle. I love this thing, even if it is a bit heavy and awkward. This is far more badassed than an AR or an AK. Surplus ammo is cheap and you can get various fire hazard colored tip ammo for it at Tanner. Only thing you don't want to shoot through it is Turkish as it is loaded too hot. Yugo, FN, German all run fine. Gas can be adjusted depending on ammo used.

I'm listing this at $575 CASH right now.

Prefer cash to trades at this time.  I am including a LOT of top quality ammo with this in hope of a quick sale.  I still need to count it, but it is at least 300 rds of the good stuff (no cheap crap).  With the hi-caps, book, and ammo it is worth several hundred more than my asking price, but I know I'm not going to get top dollar for MilSurp in this economy.

This is CASH price.  If you want to make an offer, please be reasonable and willing to negotiate.  If you want to offer a trade, please be fair.  No, you cannot disassemble the rifle before lowballing me.  No lookie-loos.  This is a nice, solid, reliable autoloading rifle in 8mm Mauser.  It is worth significantly more than my asking price.

No bad guys or loonies.  Thanks.

title: For Sale/Trade:  Remington Nylon 66 Rifle Mohawk Brown
location: Louisburg, Raleigh / Durham / CH, North Carolina
postcontent: We have here for sale a Remington Nylon 66 Rifle .22LR. Serial # (none visible). The Remington Nylon 66 .22 is made of DuPont Zytel, a synthetic material that does not require lubrication, from the beginning, these rifles have been very desirable in cold climates such as Alaska. Nowadays the Nylon 66’s, in all their colors, are quite desirable Collector’s items, and they are still a fun gun to shoot. This tube-fed rifle is in the “Mohawk Brown” color, and it is in overall very good condition. The finish rates about 90%, the blueing is still strong. The synthetic stock rates about 90%, with some very slight service scratches on the bottom. The bore is very good. As these rifles become more collectible their prices will continue to increase, and they will always be fine shooters. I do not have the box for this rifle. I may ship this one if the price is right. They're on GB for anywhere from $250 to $400 in this condition so I'll say $300 will take it.

Black, 12 gauge, 28 inch barrel, 3 1/2 inch chamber. Been fired less than 100 times and in fantastic shape. Comes with all 3 chokes it comes with new, and the tool to take them in and out. In excellent shape. Also comes with a camo soft case that fits the gun really well. Excellent all purpose gun. 

Description from Benelli:

Back when everyone thought that the pump action shotgun couldn't be improved, the Benelli Nova Pump proved otherwise. Completely original and innovative, the 20-gauge or 12-gauge pump incorporates a polymer stock and lightweight receiver into a single unit for unsurpassed strength and weather resistance. Italian styling and high-tech ergonomics make the gun not only pleasing to look at, but a delight to hold and handle. Distinctive grooves on the pistol grip and forend in place of conventional checkering provides a positive gripping surface and complements the innovative engineering of the Nova Pump. With dual-action bars and rotary head locking lugs, the Nova 12-gauge shotgun and 20-gauge shotgun handle anything from target loads to 3-1/2" magnums. Available in Black Synthetic, Realtree MAX-4® and new Realtree APG® finishes, and as a youth model, the Benelli Nova Pump is the most versatile pump action shotgun ever made.

title: For Sale:  Hakim, Turkish Mauser, HUGE lot of ammo, extras   SPF
postcontent:
SOLD PENDING FUNDS


I have decided to get rid of all my 8mm Mauser stuff.

THIS IS BEING SOLD AS A LOT, DEEPLY DISCOUNTED AT HALF PRICE, DO NOT ASK ME TO PART THIS LOT OUT AT THE DISCOUNTED PRICE.

I originally had my Hakim rifle posted.  Just looked it over and needed to make a correction.  Hi-caps are 25 rd and 30 rd.  10 rd also included.  Compatible with stripper clips.  Hi-cap mags go for between $75 and $100 each when you can find them.

I am adding a beautiful Turkish Mauser to the lot.  This is the nicest one I've ever seen and is valued at about 200.  I have a bullet band for the stock and a shell loop sling, both brand new and in original packaging.  Have a new Garand sling for the Hakim as well.  I have a broken shell extractor tool, also brand new in package.

I am including ALL my 8mm Mauser ammo, including some incredibly rare and expensive collectable ammo.  I have a full box of Italian green tip AP, a full box of German WP that was pulled and reloaded by Yugo military, 20 rds of blue tip from Denver Bullets, and a full box of (new) Hi-Shok soft point hunting ammo as well as approximately 400 additional rounds of FMJ, most of which is non-corrosive.  Only a single small box of crap 50s Yugo.  The AP and WP rounds alone are valued at over $100.  This is the real stuff, not repainted tips.  I'm guessing about $350 worth of ammo here, maybe more.

I already told you about the Hakim.  Rifle alone, without the extra mags, is worth about $500.  I'm going to cut and paste the data from the original ad below:

This is a Hakim battle rifle chambered for 8mm Mauser. Very few were imported and many of the ones available are not in good shape. This is one of the nicer ones I've seen. Bore is clean, overall condition is Excellent. This rifle was very well taken care of by the prior owner. Functions flawlessly according to prior owner, and it feeds and extracts snap caps well.

Detachable magazine, high powered military round, well designed muzzle brake to eliminate recoil, and a blow forward brass deflector that doubles as the charging handle. Very unique design.

In addition to the standard 10 rd mag, I also have a couple of hi-caps: a 20 rd Federal and a 25 rd ribbed MG-13 mag that was adapted to fit by a Hakim expert (cost nearly a hundred bucks on gunbroker, but it is a good one). Comes with a sling, gas tool, tech sheet, a good book about this rifle, and I can add a few hundred rounds of good quality ammo as well (most of it is non-corrosive, no bulk garbage here). Does NOT come with bayonet in pic.

Pic from original sale thread below. Extra hi-cap mag (of much better quality) not in pic.

Surplus ammo is cheap.  Only thing you don't want to shoot through it is Turkish as it is loaded too hot. Yugo, FN, German all run fine. Gas can be adjusted depending on ammo used.

Let's see . . . $500 Hakim, $200 Mauser, $200 worth of hi-cap mags, $350 worth of ammo, easily another $50+ in assorted extras.  Holy crap, I invested well over $1200 in this caliber.

FOR EVERYTHING IN THE LOT

I am asking $725 obo.

That is a really good deal.  Selectively open to trades, but that is a CASH price, not a trade value price.  Make your offer a fair one.  Thanks.

postcontent: This gun is probably 30 years old. Detonics was the First chopped 1911 that hit the market. Made in Seattle Washington. 3 inch barrel. 6 round magazine. Satin finish Hard Chromed. Has a couple of shiney spots from carrying it. Finish is not rubbed off, just got shiner in those spots from carrying. To make it smaller, the beavertail was removed. title: For Sale:  NIB Kel-Tec P3AT in Custom Brown Billfold color
postcontent:
The guns are new in the box with all factory documentation, etc.

P-3AT (Custom Billfold Brown Color)
The P-3AT is a semi-automatic, locked breech pistol, chambered for the .380 Auto cartridge. It has been developed from our highly successful P-32 pistol with negligible increase in weight and size. The slidestop has been eliminated and the magazine capacity reduced to 6 rounds due to the larger cartridge. The firing mechanism is double action only. The magazine has a 6 round capacity. The KEL-TEC P-3AT is the lightest .380 Auto pistol ever made. Thanks to its locking dynamics and superior ergonometry, perceived recoil and practical accuracy are comparable to much larger guns. The P-3AT is mainly intended for plainclothes police officers as a secondary weapon, or for concealed carry by licensed citizens. The small grip size and light trigger pull make the P-3AT ideal for female shooters.

TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS
Calibers:	.380 AUTO
Weight unloaded:	8.3 oz.	235g
Loaded magazine:	2.8 oz.	81g
Length:	5.2"	132mm
Height:	3.5"	89mm
Width:	.77"	20mm
Barrel Length:	2.7"	68mm
Sight radius:	3.8"	97mm
Muzzle Energy Max:	250ft-lbs	340J
Capacity:	6 + 1 rounds
Trigger Pull:	5 lbs	23N

The P-3AT has five main component groups: barrel, slide, firing mechanism, grip, and magazine. The barrel is made of SAE 4140 ordnance steel, heat treated to 48 HRC. The slide is also 4140 steel, and contains the firing pin and the extractor. The rectangular frame is machined from solid 7075-T6 aluminum and houses the firing mechanism. The trigger connects via a transfer bar to the hammer. The hammer is driven by a novel free floating extension spring. The light weight firing pin transmits the energy of the hammer to ignite the primer. After firing, the hammer block holds the hammer away from the firing pin, providing a mechanical safety.

title: For Sale/Trade:  * * * * *   SAIGA 12  * * * * *  GET ONE WHILE YOU CAN!
postcontent:
To those who bought a Saiga 12 months or years ago, my hat is off to you for buying when there was a glut in the market. Now for the rest of you listen up. 


The Saiga 12 is a magazine loaded 12 gauge shotgun that is capable of inflicting severe damage, so much so that the BATF has banned their import temporarily and will release their permanent ban on May 1 st . I believe that these will be found by the BATF as “destructive devices” and if so will require a $200 tax stamp to purchase one IF (huge if) one can be found. These are similar to the USAs-12 which were available to the public briefly then banned by the ATF. There are no more of these coming into the country, give Arsenal a call and find out for yourself. You can’t find these at gun shows because they are gone. This is your only warning: Buy now and save $$$ or pay through the nose later IF you can find one. 


Note on converting these to accept AK-47 furniture. This is a simple process a trained monkey or child could do in less than 2 hours, don’t waste your time paying someone an outrageous amount of money. Watch the videos on www.youtube.com   and it’s a snap. All you need is a dremil tool and/or die grinder, drill, drill bits, flat head screw driver and a pair of needle nose pliers. 



FOR SALE: Saiga 12. Unmodified, brand new in the box straight from Arsenal. These are the 109 version which have the bolt-hold open function, these come with (1) 5 round mag, cleaning kit and paper work. As a bonus I am going to include a $30 Tapco G2 trigger group, you will need this if you want to convert your Saiga. 


I am considering reasonable cash offers and trades, these sell on gunbroker all day long for $900 so dreamers will be ignored. 

Video of a converted Saiga 12 ~   http://youtu.be/bsx1uD3QZ54 


I prefer face to face with Florida ID, will ship to FFL for additional fee.

Felons, Illegal immigrants, Crazy people or those that can not own/purchase a firearm legally don't bother contacting me.

postcontent: J. Stevens Falling Block Type Lever Action Rifle, which I believe to be a Model 44. 26” part octagon/part round barrel… marked “J. STEVENS A. & T. CO.” “CHICOPEE FALLS MASS U.S.A. PAT. APR.17.94”. I believe the caliber this rifle to .25 rimfire. The rifle is marked with the number 22 under the forearm. It appears to have a case hardened frame with what would have originally been a blued barrel… oil finished walnut straight grip stock and forearm. The wood exhibits no visible splits or cracks, but does have a very small piece missing from the right side of the butt stock above the lever action. Fixed front sight, buckhorn rear sight and vernier tang sight. This is a numbers matching rifle of which the serial number is 2788. Overall, this firearm appears to be complete and in very good condition with a tight action and good bore. This firearm is being sold as a collector piece only. Ammunition for this caliber is extremely rare and probably costly. It appears to be functional, but I have not fired it and would advise anyone who may want to do so to have this weapon thoroughly inspected by a qualified gunsmith. This is only the second J. Stevens rifle to come in here on consignment… I am not an expert on these types of rifles, but I have tried my best to describe it accurately, any and all information anyone would like to provide about this firearm would be very much appreciated.
